When it comes to titrating concentrated sulfuric acid (H2SO4) with a calcium carbonate (CaCO3) standard and trying to achieve an accurate result,11, there's a significant issue that arises.

To avoid this issue,1975, it is generally recommended to use a different standard, and/or employ alternative methods for determining the concentration of concentrated sulfuric acid, I'd recommend using a sodium hydroxide or potassium hydroxide standard instead, as these strong bases don't form precipitates with sulfuric acid.
To overcome this issue, is crucial to use a different indicator or a stronger base like sodium hydroxide (NaOH) as a titrant, (standard solution) instead of calcium carbonate.

In addition, and to make matters worse, as calcium sulfate precipitates out of solution, Aand because calcium sulfate has a relatively low solubility product (Ksp), even small amounts of impurities or contamination in the reaction vessel can also lead to premature precipitation, the effective concentration of the calcium carbonate standard is altered further affecting the accuracy of the titration.

To avoid this issue,  it is more common to use a sodium hydroxide (NaOH) or other strong base standard instead of calcium carbonate when performing acid-base titrations involving concentrated sulfuric acid.

To overcome this limitation, alternative methods or standards can be employed, such as using a sodium carbonate (Na2CO3) or potassium hydroxide (KOH) standard instead, which do not form precipitates with sulfuric acid and thus provide more accurate results in the titration of concentrated sulfuric acid.assistant
